newsitem.title: USA: SOCCER-L.A. GALAXY WIN FIFTH CONSECUTIVE GAME.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-L.A. GALAXY WIN FIFTH CONSECUTIVE GAME.

text.p: Harut Karapetyan broke a 1-1 tie with five minutes remaining to lift the surging Los Angeles Galaxy to their fifth consecutive win, a 2-1 victory over the Colorado Rapids in Major League Soccer action on Sunday.
Brazilian Welton also scored for the Galaxy (9-11), while Chris Henderson converted a penalty kick for the Rapids (10-12).

In East Rutherford, New Jersey, Colombian international Antony De Avila set up the equaliser and scored the game-winner with eight minutes remaining to give the New York/New Jersey MetroStars (7-12) a 2-1 victory over D.C. United (14-7).
U.S. national team captain John Harkes had given United a 1-0 lead in the 60th minute, but Venezuelan forward Giovanni Savarese tied it 11 minutes later.

In Columbus, Ohio, the Tampa Bay Mutiny (12-10) survived a scoreless tie in regulation and a shootout with the Columbus Crew (8-12) to register a 1-0 win. The Mutiny outscored the Crew in the tie-breaker, 3-1.

In other weekend action, in Washington, D.C., Bolivian international midfielder Marco Etcheverry scored his first goal of the year, with two minutes remaining in regulation, and converted a shootout attempt as United snapped a two-game losing game with a 2-1 win over Columbus.
Kris Kelderman and Roy Wegerle also scored in the tie-breaker as goalkeeper Scott Garlick made one save. Raul Diaz Arce had his MLS record point streak snapped at 10 games.
Pete Marino scored the lone goal for the Crew, who have lost nine of their last 11 games.

In Dallas, Ecuadoran Eduardo Hurtado scored twice in the second half to spark the Los Angeles Galaxy to their fourth consecutive victory, a 3-0 triumph over the Dallas Burn (12-10), who had their four-game winning streak snapped.

El Salvadoran Mauricio Cienfuegos scored the Galaxy's first goal, and Mexican goalkeeper Jorge Campos set up Hurtado's first score, knocking down a cross and dribbling to midfield before he gave the ball to Hurtado, who fired in a 30-yard shot.

In San Jose, California, former U.S. international defender Steve Trittchuh and Mexican David Patino scored early and late in the opening half, respectively, to give the Colorado Rapids a 2-1 win over the San Jose Clash (7-15).

El Salvadoran Ron Cerritos extended his point streak to eight games by assisting on a goal by Clash teammate Chris Sullivan. The Clash, who have the league's worst record, have dropped four straight matches.

In Kansas City, Missouri, the Wizards (14-7), who were stunned by the third division San Francisco Bay Seals in the third round of the U.S. Open Cup on Thursday, managed to rebound with a 1-0 shootout victory over the New England Revolution (12-9).
The Wizards won the tie-breaker, 4-3, after playing to a scoreless tie in regulation. Matt McKeon, Mark Chung, Paul Wright and Preki converted their shootout chances.
